data.title: Pack a picnic and head to one of these local sites
data.meta_description: What better way to enjoy the valley's picturesque parks and playgrounds than to pack a picnic basket and head out for a day of fun in the sun?
data.text:
Spring is in the air and what better way to enjoy the valley's picturesque parks and playgrounds than to pack a picnic basket filled with your favorite goodies and a comfortable blanket, and leave your electronics behind.

Katie Randall loves to picnic in the local parks with her husband Juan Angel and their 7-year-old daughter Stella.

“We picnicked at Peach Hill Park in Poughkeepsie and loved that (we) were in the trees, with almost no one else around and lots of space for kids to run and play,” said the Hopewell Junction resident and founder of Katie’s Hudson Valley Travel Blog. “Plus, you can pick apples if it's apple season.”

She’s also taken her family for a picnic at Trevor Zoo in Millbrook.

“It’s one of my most favorite places to picnic,” she said. “We sit right by the emus in the shade or down by the otters and listen to the waterfalls.”

There are plenty of wonderful places to picnic in Dutchess County. Here are some to sample:

Upper Landing Park

Located in the City of Poughkeepsie, right on the banks of the Hudson River, Upper Landing Park not only offers splendid views for a picnic, but the area is steeped in history. It was once used as a hunting and fishing ground for Native Americans and has served as a homestead, mill site, commercial dock, Revolutionary War depot, industrial hub and electrical power generation source.

“The property has a rich history going back to the late 1600s and there is interpretive signage throughout the park that tells this story,” said Theresa Gill, director of administration at the Dyson Foundation, which owns the park. “It’s beautiful and quaint. Some have even referred to it as serene.”

The park, which is open from 7 a.m. to sunset, offers limited amenities — a water fountain and portable toilets — and there are a handful of picnic tables and benches available, or you can bring a blanket. Barbecuing and alcoholic beverages are prohibited.

“The experience of resting beside the river in an unhurried and peaceful environment is totally worth the visit,” Gill said.

Go: 83 North Water St., Poughkeepsie; 845-834-2867; http://upperlanding.org

While you’re there: The Mid-Hudson Children’s Museum and the Walkway Over the Hudson are literally steps away. The Mid-Hudson Children’s Museum at 75 North Water St. has exhibits for young children that focus on literacy, art, health and community (http://mhcm.org/). If you want to walk off the picnic you just ate, stroll onto the Walkway Over the Hudson (or take the elevator from Upper Landing Park), which is 1.28 miles long and is free year-round, except for the Fourth of July. 61 Parker Ave., Poughkeepsie (http://walkway.org/).

Innisfree Garden

This scenic150-acre garden in Millbrook was originally created for Walter Beck and his wife, avid gardener and heiress Marion Burt Beck, and features a beautiful combination of wildflowers, streams, waterfalls, terraces and plants based on principles of Chinese landscape design.

“Innisfree is an extraordinary picnic destination,” said Kate Kerin, landscape curator at Innisfree Garden. “It is full of enough excitement and wonder to entertain families all day. The history and design speak to the most discerning connoisseurs and is one of the most romantic places ever. As a special treat, Innisfree opens an hour before sunrise three times each year. Come then for an unforgettable sunrise picnic.”

Innisfree Garden has public restrooms in the parking area and a designated picnic area. Hours are 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. from April 15-30 only on weekends and holidays. After April 30, the site is open from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Wednesday-Friday; and 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Saturday-Sunday, and holidays. Admission is $8 until April 30 and then $6 during the week and $8 on weekends until Oct. 15. Children under 3 and members are free.

Go: 362 Tyrell Road, Millbrook; 845-677-8000; http://www.innisfreegarden.org/

While you’re there: The Trevor Zoo, 282 Millbrook School Road, Millbrook, is only minutes away from Innisfree Garden. Here kids can see red pandas, owls, otters and many more animals. Open from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day, admission is $6 for adults; $4 for children 3-13. 845-677-3704; https://www.millbrook.org/page/trevor-zoo-home

Poets’ Walk Park

It is said that Washington Irving came up with the idea for his legendary story “Rip Van Winkle” while strolling this 120-acre parcel of land and that other literary figures have walked in this park, too. Who knows if you’ll be inspired to write the next greatest literary work here, but this park in Red Hook does inspire the romance of a picnic.

“Research shows that being in nature eases stress, inspires us and provides overall positive feelings,” said Jay Burgess, Scenic Hudson director of Communications for Poets’ Walk. “When you’re in this 120-acre Scenic Hudson park, you’ll feel fully immersed in the beauty and calm of the outdoors.”

When you’re done with your picnic, even the kids will love the two miles of trails to explore, including a universally accessible trail.

“It’s through woods and rolling meadows with rustic cedar pavilions, footbridges and benches, and Hudson River views,” Burgess said.

Go: 776 River Road, Red Hook; 845-473-4440; https://www.scenichudson.org/parks/poetswalk

While you’re there: There is plenty to do in the Red Hook area, but take in a little history at Montgomery Place, a 380-acre estate that is a designated National Historic Landmark. The estate, at 25 Gardener Way in Annandale, was owned by the Livingston family. The grounds are open every day from dawn to dusk and mansion tours will begin again in June. 845-752-500; http://www.bard.edu/montgomeryplace

Locust Grove

Overlooking the Hudson River in Poughkeepsie is the 200-acre estate that was the home of artist and inventor Samuel Morse. Today you can enjoy sitting at the designated picnic area on the property where surrounded by beautifully landscaped grounds and historic gardens.

“Locust Grove is the perfect antidote to the busy Route 9 retail corridor,” said Kenneth F. Snodgrass, executive director of The Locust Grove Estate & Locust Lawn Farm. “If you want to enjoy a peaceful picnic, but don’t have time to drive to the mountains, you can pull off the road, enjoy a comfortable picnic table in the shade, and still have time to finish your errands.”

The grounds are open 8 a.m. to dusk, year-round and no alcoholic beverages are permitted.

Go: 2683 Route 9, Poughkeepsie; 845-454-4500; http://www.lgny.org

While you’re there: The Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar College, 124 Raymond Ave, Poughkeepsie, is a great way to enjoy some culture when you’re done with your picnic. Take in the wide range of artworks by Hudson River School artists to the works of major European and American 20th-century painters. 845-437-5237; https://fllac.vassar.edu

Vanderbilt Mansion

The Vanderbilt Mansion National Historic Site in Hyde Park belonged to socially prominent New Yorkers for more than 200 years. This historic home is surrounded by gorgeous landscapes, gardens and woodlands and, of course, a place to picnic. Enjoy what the Vanderbilts got to enjoy for many, many years.

“One Mother’s Day, we had the entire north wall filled with picnickers,” said Mike Autenrieth, Vanderbilt Mansion park ranger. “There is a stately nature to the property and you have this beautiful view of the Hudson and formal gardens. It really is a treat.”

Go: 4097 Route 9, Hyde Park; 845-229-7770; https://www.nps.gov/vama/index.htm

While you’re there: In the mood for more opulence? Then check out the Staatsburgh State Historic Site on Old Post Road in Staatsburg, which was the country home of Ogden Mills and his wife Ruth Livingston Mills, built during the Guilded Age. Tours are available from April 19 through Oct. 28: 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., Thursday-Sunday, last tour at 4 p.m. 845-889-8851; https://parks.ny.gov/historic-sites/25/details.aspx

Val-Kill

Val-Kill was Eleanor Roosevelt’s home in Hyde Park; she and her family loved to picnic on the grounds, and you will, too.

“There’s a lovely pond where you can see the ducks and get a feeling of history in the making,” said Fran Macsali-Urbin, Val-Kill’s supervisory park ranger. “The Roosevelts brought world leaders here and the president and first lady had picnics all the time in the summer.”

Picnickers can bring blankets but no grills, and there is no cost to picnic on the property. Take a tour of the cottage when you are done with your picnic. There is an admission fee to tour the home.

Go: 4097 Route 9, Hyde Park; 845-229-9422; https://www.nps.gov/elro/index.htm

While you’re there: Not far from Val-Kill is the historic Hyde Park Train Station, where you can see the history of and learn about different trains. There are special programs for children and adults every month, including history nights that are held the first Monday of each month at 7 p.m. 34 River Road, Hyde Park; http://www.hydeparkstation.com

Peach Hill Park

There are 159 acres of land at Peach Hill Park, which has been used for agricultural purposes since the 19th century. The park is open every day from sunrise to sunset. There are trails and designated picnic areas.

Go: 32 Edgewood Drive in Poughkeepsie; http://peach-hill-park.org
